PDS users cannot claim that they havent received a document because it is very for edocs to check whether the document is in the PDS
PDS users can change their information after logging in
No harm can be done creating a new user for the PDS regarding tampering or information disclosure since it would involve your own PDS
It is impossible to register a new user if the username or emailaddress are already in use
the delivery manager and scheduler are deployed on the same physical node
the PDS docs and PDS user data are deployed on the same physical node
External delivery services are assumed to be professionally enough and have proper authentication handling
PDS user logs in via browser and uses credentials
A13+ visits of a user to the PDS are logged
The document ID cannot be guessed and an adversary cannot change the delivery status of documents as a consequence
The delivery scheduler has no flows going outside the trust boundary (+A1)
the generated docs archive has no flow going outside the trust boundary
No authentication when creating a new PDS user
Tampering with documents is not possible as they are not changed after creationg and customer organisations are not considered here
Tampering with user dara is not considered except for threat T6 in which is the info is tampered with at creation
Information disclosure of PDS user data is considered impossible as the PDS proces (p3) never sends it anywhere and itis safe angainst code & memory level attacks

All information sent over channels in the trust boundary (DF11-DF23) is either over internal infrastructure or encrypted. As such the data can not be tampered with or be discoed as edocs employees are considered trustworthy
Information disclosure through sidechannels is considered nowehere as the difficulty for such an attack would make it not the worth it for edocs data
As logs are never mentioned in the description of the edocs system, it is assumed no logs are kept
eDocs employees can access the data stores from the outside
Spoofing of E1,E2 and E3 does not happen as they are explicity know by the system
There is little benefit to setting wrong (delivery) statuses
E1, E2, and E3 have an SLA with eDocs
Repudiation by a PDS user is considered to be too unlikely (no motivation) to be considered a threat
Repudiation by P1-P3 is not considered as threats originate outside of the trust boundary
As logs are maintained for every step in the generation and delivery process we assume repudiation is not possible for the PDS user
Some logs are kept in the PDS store to log who performed what actions
DF11,DF12 and DF13 are inside the trust boundary and have no dirct external influences so it is assumed that these three flows are not threatened b tampering or informatnion disclosure

We assume passwords can only be changed after confirmation mails

The external services and the delivery manager are protected against upstream insertion

Since data flow (DF11-DF20) all contains very similar assets (documents,ids, statuses) and it's apparently easier to observe data flow between PDS and a data store (DF19,DF20). So I assume DF19 and DF20 are easier to be attacked. Therefore DF11-DF18 has low priority for ID threats

Data flow between PDS and User data store (DFS21-DS23) should have higher priority than DF19 and DF20, because user data is much easier to make use. And since the attacker gets user data,it's easier for the attacker to login to PDS and get specific documents of these users.

The systems reputation is high enough to attract attackers (and wanting to cause harm)
The PDS keeps adequate logs about the users actions. Therefore, users can not deny having made some actions, such as reading a document

DS1,DS2,DS3 are only accessible by P1, P2, P3. Thus, P1-3 cant be spoofed to the datastores, e.g. P3 runs on the same physical node as DS2 and DS3, so they are not coneected over Internet. Tampering & ID are therefore impossible
All encrypted communication can be read by the receiver only, an assymetric encryption scheme is used
All datastores keep logs of every action that is undertaken. Once logged, an  entry in the log is immutable
E1,E2,E3 can not be spoofed. Due to the assumption A2, an attacker can not send meaningful messages to the system in their name, nor can he interpret messages obtained by name squatting
E1,E2 and E3 will deny neither the reception of a document for delivery nor the delivery of a document, since this would cost them money (assumption: they are paid per document that is delivered)

Due to the encryption of dataflows between E1 E2 and E3 and P2, P2 is immune to tampering by passing malicious parameters. Attackers can not construct messages to P2 since they do not have the encryption key (in contrast to the communication between E4 and P3)
The data flow between P2 and E3 are not encrypted
P1, P2, P3 can each be deployed on a different node
DS1 and DS2 are replicated on multiple nodes
The PDS and PDS user data (DS3) are on the same node and their data flows are encrypted (DF21,22,23)
eDocs admins are only allowed to log in in house
PDS users are unable to request any information of other users
The delivery manager and scheduler and the PDS and the PDS process only communicate through local network, preventing internal data flow attacks
External delivery services can not request sending a specific document
We use well-established printing service companies and send docs automatically. There there is no risk of spoofing and repudiation
Zoomit is wellknown service and all communication is automated. We assume, since zoomit handles bank info, that zoomit is protected against attackers getting access to docs
Our emails are sent inhouse and therefore the email provider is not vulnerable to spoofing (DF4-5,E3)
PDS users are authenticated by means of credentials
All input is verified, queries in databases use precautions to counter against SQL injections
The system provides interfaces/facades that limit access to it. All communication goes through them
A PDS user can only read documents from the PDS docs (DS2) so it cannot be tampered
Whenever PDS user registers, the mail address is verified so that only the actual owner of the email address can use it and obtain all docs linked to it
The print service and zoomit are properly authenticated. data that is sent, is signed so the sender can be verified
The delivery scheduler and generated docs archive can only be accessed by internal processes
Each generated document is delivered at least once
The delivery manager will only retrieve documents from DS1 when told to by the scheduler
The delivery manager will only deliver messages when told to by the scheduler
When a user registers he receives a randomly generated password that can be changed if wanted
Altering a document has no effect on the actual payment depending on the document
Zoomit and emailprovider can not request documents
The generated docs archive will never alter documents nor ids, only status info
Status info updates can only follow this order: (to prevent resending and hiding docs): received data->generating->generated->sent->delivered->read
The delivery manager keeps no information of a customer organisation or client
It's not possible for a PDS user to delete a doc
It's not pssoble to tamper with internal connections or components without access from an outside component (e.g. DF14 cannot be listened in on)
PDS user is authenticated by means of credentials
It's not possible to spoof someone's real life address (eg steal his postal mail)
Resending a document never implies it is billed multiple times
It's not posible to alter a PDF
The sensitive information in PDS user data (DS3) is hashed in order to keep it secure
The print service, zoomit and the email provider have no gain to repudiate. Therefore, we can assume the repudiation threat can be ignored for them.
All external entities (E1-E4) are authenticated by means of credentials. The implementation of the authentication is secure
All external entities (E1-E4) are authenticated by means of credentials. The implementation of the authentication is secure
The print service, zoomit and the email provider are expected to be trustworthy. So they are expected to be able to keep their credentials secret.
Each of the invoices is signed with a key and cannot be tampered with without removing the signature
There is no identification by IP address to the send services.
There is no limit to the amount of shipments on the send services
A document with tracking for an unregistred user has a public link
All customer organization employees can be trusted on the fact that they dont send illegal/spam mailing
The E-mail provider is a secure environment. Only authenticationusers have access to send data
A document can be accessed unlimited times
PDS docs and PDS user data contain no logs
Every entity is identified with credentials
The PDS can be accessed by internet
Edocs has an SLA with every delivery service
There is not worthwhile action a PDS user wants to repudiate
its not possible to information disclosure from DF1,2,3,6,7,8,9,10 because of A2
Its not possible to disclose information from P1 because it's not connected to an external entity
Its not possible to tamper or disclose information from the DFs 11-13 because it's traffic between P1 and DS1
The printer service cannot be spoofed because no incoming request/dataflow is sent by this service\
the PDS user logs in by means of credentials
Data flows 1,2,3,6,7,8,9,10 are not considered as a "tamperng threat" because of A2
It's not possible to spoof P1 because it only receives requests via DS1, not from external entitiy
Its not possible to tamper a process because of A3
For zoomit delivery, a credit card number is provided
A credit card number is saved in the PDS user data
the PDS user logs in by means of credentials
Payslip/invoice does not contain very sensitive information
There is no reason for attacker to read delivery notification (DF5)
DF5 is only used to notify the system of delivery of a document or of the failure of a delivery
DF5 is only used to notify system of doc delivery
Delivery manager only provides interface for acknowledging received, reporting errors (no queries)
There is no need for logging in for services in the delivery manager. All info is added by eDocs operators
dataflows inside trust boundary are considered secure
databases are secured against attacks (like SQL injections)
eDocs operators are trustworthy, so no untrustworthy privacy service, zoomit, or email provider can be added
Proper non-repudiation mechanism for users and services is provided so they cannot repudiate
Data stores are type checked and do not allow bad data
Logs are encrypted and hash of logs is stored elsewhere
the PDS user logs in by means of credentials
Email provider has deal about security with our company
dataflows between processes are encrypted and have confidentiality and integrity
Access to data stores is authenticated and encrypted
the PDS user logs in by means of credentials
DF3 and DF5 can only be used for delivery notification
DF4 and DF5 are not encrypted
eDocs has direct channel to print service, zoomit and email provider and no entity can pose as one of them
Through DF3, any registration/configuration with zoomit is setup as well
Zoomit is not prone to security leaks
The Email provider is not prone to security leaks
The Emailprovider is not prone to security leaks
The PDS user is authenticated by means of credentials
The PDS user makes use of an authentication UI
The PDS user can reset credentials though email
Any receipt tracking of documents is tracked server side and thus is reliable (and is logged)
Processes P1, P2, P3 write right logs and admin access
Login credentials are encrypted using MD5 encryption
Documents are password protected
The document archive (DS2) contains correctly generated documents
The PDS users are authenticated by means of credentials
The services like Zoomit and Email providers are authenticated by public key
All flow between delivery manager and E-mail provider are not encrypted
Logs are only stored in DS3
No data can be inserted in DS2, because that functionality is only internally available
All entities will explicitly acknowledge receival of a message
After individual authentication, individual requests are not checked for validity
SQL injection protection is not in place
Communication within the system can not be altered or leaked, cf also A1,A3
All delivery channels (E1, E2, E3) are sufficiently protected against internal attacks
All delivery channels (E1,E2,E3) are sufficiently protected against internal attacks
E1 is a respected company and has nothing to win by repudiating document deliveries/receivals. It has a reputation to hold high
Every sending component only discloses as much information as is necessary for the receiving component to do its job properly.
A registered recipient needs to log in before accessing the document to which he/she has received a link in a notification mail
E2 and E3 send a confirmaition to P2 upon receival
E4 sends a confirmation to P3 upon receival
DF12 only contains the necessary info for P1 to function properly. This information is not distributed any further along the channel if it is not necessary

The communication between delivery scheduler , P1 and generated docs archive DS1 is considered to (be) secured since it are internal communcation flows of the system. Thus the dataflows: P1->DS1 and DS1-> P1 are considered to be safew
The flows P1->P2, P2->DS1, P2->P3, P2->P3 are considered secure since it are internal comminication flows of edocs entities
The flows P3->P2, P3->P2, P3->DS2,DS2->P3 are considered secure since it are internal comminication flows of edocs entities
The flows P3->DS2,P3->DS2,DS3->P3 are considered secure since it are internal comminication flows of edocs entities
Passwords cant be changed by other people than the user
The PDS is sufficiently secure (so) that gaining full access is impossible without the right credentials
Print and .. logs are correct and secure/Delivery schedler and manager are secure in  way that the system can be sure of what was sent
It has no use to spoof P1 and P2 because they can get access to important information.The only mehtods that they can do is send a document and accept delivery of a document
The contact information is given in the meta data of the document. The A2 says that it wont be changed. Therefore the documents will be delivered at the right address
Because everyone needs to log in before something can be added/changed to the system, no one can without permission change something in the system.
A mail is sent to the mail address which is given when creating an account. The mail eneds to be received and accepted before the account is activated
Before something can be retrieved, someone needs to log in and have the permission to retrieve it
Print service, zoomit and mail provider are secure enough so that they cant be spoofed (they use secure keys)
PDS users log in using credentials
WHen a document is retrieved from the PDS, this retrieval is documented and saved. The system cant use repudiation (sic)
Good access control in DS1-3; so no info is leaked and tampered requests are ignored. Tampered request= user asks for doc1, tampered req asks for doc 2(of another user)
PDS login happens through an email address and a password
there are multiple instances of P2-P3 and can be spoofed. P1 and DS1-3 can not be spoofed
Tampering with DF3 and DF5 is no problem. It could be that documents would be resent but that is very unlikely and irrelevant
DF14 seems irrelevant because P2 can only read from DS1 but no response is possible. Thus DF14 is ignored.
DF11 and DF12 are completely trusted since P1 and DS1 connot be directly attacked
DF4 and DF5 are encrypted and are considered to have channel confidentiality and integrity
Repudiation for E4 (and P3) is no threat. We dont care if he reads his own documents or not. Since no write are issued, this is OKay.
The threats for P1 are irrelevant since the implementaiton is good and no attackers can reach it from outside. (See A1 and A3). It can not be reverse-engineered
Credentials are hashed and salt is added so a spoofing PDS can not dump DS3
The PDS can access all documents in PDS docs and all the user information
The delivery scheduler and delivery manager are on the same machine. The PDS and the data stores are each on another machine
PDS user can only view its own documents
Only documents and their metadata are sent to the delivery channels (e.g. not the SLAs)
Receiving a document twice doesnt mean you have to pay twice
The delivery scheduler can only receive new documents that didn already pass through him
spoofing the print service is no threat because there is no data flow from the print service back to the delivery manager
The print service/zoomit/mail provider are trustworthy partners
Zoomit and the mail provider have secure policy for storing credentials
Data flows within the trust boundary cannot be attacked (DF11-DF23)
DF4 and DF5 are not encrypted and thus have no channel confidentiality/integrity
A proper framework is used while generating the documents. Hence the threat level is very negligible
A cross check is done after every implementation so that memory level manipulation is ensured (SIC)
The generated docs archive maintains integrity
The delivery manager will make sure that the delivery channels are trustworthy
The data flows between PDS (P3) and E4 (PDS user) is encrypted (DF6,DF7,DF9, DF10) so that tampering of data can be reduced
The data stored in PDS are restricted with permission credentials where  only trusted people can access at
All the dataflows within turst boundary are all encrypted
The development, testing, maintenance, implementating, everything is secured.
While giving login credentials to users or while users setting the login credentials should allow all instruction given so that the chances of threats are less
Every entity should maintain the crosscheck in each and every step
Entities should maintain integrity
Confidential information should not be stored with someone who is not authorized
Professional ethics should be maintained by every one and should misutilize properties as personal
The generated documents are well-maintained so as to ensure security
The stored documents in generated docs archive are given with strong permission credentials so that authorized users can assess
The data flow between P2 and E3 are encrypted and integrity is maintained in a well amnner
The edocs system is divided into small parts so that it is easy to maintain the security of each and every stem (?) systems
The PDS uses sessions for logged-in users
Sending Emails via the E-mail provider is secure
The PDS user is authenticated with credentials
The print service, zoomit and mail providers are trustworthy and will not disclose documents
They (The print service, zoomit and mail providers) will never deny being sent a document
All communication within the trust boundary is safe
The employees are trained in password managment. Therefore they all have an unguessable strong password which is secretly stored in their mind
Edocs database are only accessible from within the system
When a user account is made, the email address hsould be confirmed
A PDS user is authenticated by means of credentials
All the datastores are protected (DS1,DS2, DS3)
The PDS (P3) only contains documents of a specific user
EDocs pays the mail provider per mail they send
Seen A1 and A2, the data from and to the PDS user is not vulnerable for information disclosure
DF5 is not vulnerable to information disclosure; it does not contain info useful to an outsider
PDS users can remove documents from their overview

Attacker could mail E1,E2, E4 with an email that ressembles edocs email saying it has lost its credentials. We assume that E1,E2,E3 are good enough programmed to no send credentials to a resembling address
If a user forgets his password to the PDS, his password is emailed to him
The deliverers have no way of distinguishing messages that are already sent and new messages
Edocs logins by credentials to zoomit,email provider, print service, and sends them their documents to be sent
The print service, zoomit, email provider only send documents. We assume that they want to have high profits so they wont say that they havent sent a document and miss a billing opportunity
A PDS user is authenticated by means of credentials
DF4 and DF5 do not have any encryption
We assume there are no logs held for the PDS user interaction with the PDS
We assume that either DF9 or DF10 is responsible for receipt notification
We assume for DF12, DF13, DF15,DF19 and DF20 that the document itself is sent, not a document id that is later used for document retrieval
We assume for DF12, DF13, DF15,DF19 and DF20 that the document is not used for
We assume only requests are sent in DF11, no documents
For dataflow DF14, we assume only limited request can be made (status) so impact and likelihood are very low
We assume for DF16, only minor data can be sent
We assume tthat the DS2, DS3 and P3 are thightly coupled so the likelihood of breaking in the DB is almost zero
We assume the internal working of P1,P2, and P3 are complex enough they cant be spoofed without recognition
The PDS user has received credentials at registration and uses them for authentication
For E1,E2,E3 we assume there is a good SLA and consider them services that are trustworthy
We assume that for DF4 and DF5 that the communicaion occurs with a simple SMTP servier that is not secure and easily hacked
We assume that for DF5, the email provider only sends deliverer notifications and receipt tracking info
The print service has taken security measures to prevent the takeover of its system
Spoofing an email provider only results in being able to park documents as sent. This is no useful functionality for an attacker
A PDS user is authenticated by means of credentials
The delivery scheduler is not connected durectly to systems outside of eDocs
The generated documents are valid info for the delivery scheduler, no input validation is necessary (P1)
The delivery scheduler does not deny having sent or received documents
The delivery scheduler can only communicate with parts of the eDocs system. No design-level information disclosure is possible
No tampering is possible with DF1 when using strong encryption (also for DF2, and DF3)
Communication goes over the public Internet
Email traffic is not encrypted
Email traffic is sent over the public internet
The spoofing of a print service (E1) is not applicable, since the system knows the correct delivery on only sends info to it
The print service has seigned a legally binding SLA specifiying it will print and send documents
Zoomit has signed a legally binding SLA specifying it will deliver the documents it receives
Zoomit has taken security measures to prevent the takeover of its system
DS3 passwords are not stored in plain text, with hash and salt -> even when attackers get access no immediate harm is done
When entities deny they received the data that was sent to them, it is sent again
Data sent between PDS and PDS User data is encrypted so that this very sensitive information cannot be read in data flow
Queries to the PDS datastore are not authenticated
